annotation.text: BC PLIS. Encounter information including patient class admit and attending providers
BC PLIS. Adapted for PLIS. Minimal encounter information.
(BC PLIS) changed target cmet model for BC PLIS version. Was COCT_MT090102CA.
(BC PLIS) Conformance error: optional Admitter association with empty target elements may be present in query response message.

(BC PLIS) Admitting Physician

(BC PLIS) Admitter association may be present with empty child elements in query response message. Ignore.
Associates the admitting provider (role) with the encounter.
(BC PLIS) changed target cmet model for BC PLIS version. Was COCT_MT090102CA.
(BC PLIS) Conformance error: optional Attender association with empty target elements may be present in query response message.

(BC PLIS) attending physician

(BC PLIS) Attender association may be present with empty child elements in query response message. Ignore.
Associates the attending provider (role) with the encounter or patient visit.
Describes the enounter, visit, episode between the patient and a caregiver.

(BC PLIS) HL7 V2 MAPPING

id => PV1.19 [Visit Number]

id.root => PV1.19.4.1 [Namespace ID] and PV1.19.5 [Identifier Type Code] (Combination can be used for mapping)
Services are frequently tracked, managed, and reported by encounter.
(BC PLIS) A local identifier used to identify the encounter within the sending facility.
The unique identifier for the encounter (visit, episode, etc.).
(BC PLIS) code => PV1.2 [Patient Class] (Need vocab mapping)
(BC PLIS) some implementation notes are ambiguous because they don't distinguish between the different contexts in which this cmet is used. Text needs to be clarified.
This is supplied as a categorization of locations strictly for order or result query filtering purposes.

(BC PLIS) This code identifies the encounter as inpatient or outpatient (Ambulatory).

This code categorizes the locations for request query filtering by patient location (if supported).

For labs associated with hospitals, distinguishing between inpatients and outpatients is desirable.

(BC PLIS) Vocabulary. Example: AMB - ambulatory designates an outpatient.

OID Value: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.4

Classifies the patient encounter, e.g., in the Community (practitioners office), Outpatient of a health care facility, Inpatient of a health care facility, in a Long-Term Care Facility, in the Emergency Department. This information must come in on the Order. This does not identify a specific location such as Hospital A, Room 32.
Services are frequently tracked, managed, and reported by encounter.
(BC PLIS) Date range to indicate one or both of the admit and discharge dates.
The start and stop time of the encounter (visit, episode, etc.). For inpatient encounters, this is the admit and discharge dates.
(BC PLIS) Conformance Issue: unsupported message components present in query response message as empty elements. REf # SP 341.
(BC PLIS) Not supported by PLIS but may be present in PLIS query response as empty element (with children). Ignore.
Associates the encounter or visit act with the type of service location is present at that site.
Used for reporting and categorizing results.
(BC PLIS) This identifies the type of location and maps to the service that was provided.
Information regarding the type of location where the patient had the associated encounter.
(BC PLIS) incorrect OID listed in implementation notes.
Used for reporting and categorizing results.

(BC PLIS) identifies a service area where the encounter took place.

This code may be used by a Health Care facility to indicate the nursing station or hospital service (e.g. ICU) for inpatient locations, clinic or department, or outpatient location. However, the specific location must be mapped to the standard vocabulary.

V2 mapping

code => PV1.3 [Assigned Person Location] (needs vocab mapping)

Ideally mapped to the Hospital Service PV1-10. However, in some implementations, the facility or patient location type (components of PV1-3) may be a better mapping.

OID Value: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.111

OID System Name: HL7v3 RoleCode
The type of location where the patient encounter took place (nurse station, outpatient clinical, etc.)
BC PLIS. A non-identified patient containing descriptive demographic information. Used in circumstances where resolution against a client registry is not possible
Conveys enough information to identify the patient including identifying characteristics represented as supporting clinical information. Adapted for BC PLIS.
(BC PLIS) how many alternate identifiers are supported by PLIS? The model currently allows 4.
Used for patient identification.
This role object is used to store any other patient identification identifiers.
(BC PLIS) HL7 V2 Mappings
id.extension -> Alternate Patient ID [PID-4.1]
id.root -> Identifier Type Code [PID-4.5]
id.extension -> Patient Account Number [PID-18]
id.extension -> SSN Number - Patient [PID-19]
id.extension -> Driver's License Number - Patient [PID-20]
Other identification numbers associated with identifying a patient.

(BC PLIS) Alternate identifiers for the patient (e.g. Driver's License number, Facility Chart Number, Lab Patient Identifier, MRN)

The alternate identifier includes an OID root and extension.
Alternate Identifiers for the Patient (e.g., Driver's License number, Health insurance number).

(BC PLIS) changed conformance, was mandatory. The OID will identify the type of identifier provided.

(BC PLIS) Added domain name.
(BC PLIS) Mandatory attribute not supported by PLIS.
Used to set the type of identier

(BC PLIS) Appears in messages with null flavor. (The OID in IdentifiedEntity.id identifies the type of identifier that has been provided. This is PLIS alternative to coding the identifier type here, per HL7 usage).
Describes the identification type (driver's license, etc.)

(BC PLIS) removed the following attributes - not supported by BC PLIS:

.certificateText .subjectOf.*

Information used to identify the patient and to support clinical decisions. This information applies to the person in the context of the associated action only, and should be stored separately. I.e. the address/phone/email only apply to the current prescription/dispense/lab order etc.

(BC PLIS) This patient cmet, COCT_MT050007CA, is used in multiple payload models. Uses are not all equivalent.

POLB_MT00400BC: ObservationReport.recordTarget.
A person who is receiving or may receive healthcare services and has personal attributes (e.g. name, birth date).

(BC PLIS) Conformance error: datatype error in PLIS query response message - contains empty attribute [AssigningAuthorityName=""]. Will cause schema validation to fail.
The cardinality of patient identifiers is up to 3 based on the use case to support communication of a local and jurisdictional identifier along with the national identifier.

(BC PLIS) Primary identifier of the patient (PHN is preferred)

ADD MESSAGES:

A registered MRN may be used and will resolve to a PHN.

There are circumstances where a unique identifier for the patient is not available. In this case, it is assumed that the sending application will generate a unique identifier. The identifier is an II datatype and includes an OID root and extension.

The OID root identifies the type of identifier (e.g. PHN, locally generated identifier, MRN)

(BC PLIS) In query response contains the same patient identifier also found in Message...ControlActEvent.recordTarget.patient1.id

(BC PLIS) QUERY RESPONSE. Conformance error: PLIS query response has incorrect markup in .value component of datatype. Does not follow HL7 specification. Fails schema validation. Issue #SP176.

(BC PLIS) Additional guidance for DIR: to be used for immediate direct communications between providers (e.g. pharmacist to physician for potential medication interaction issues).

(BC PLIS) Defaults for ADD / UPDATE messages.

The "useablePeriod" property is not permitted.

"use" property is required, may repeat up to three times (x_BasicTelecomAddressUse)

For telephone numbers: the telecommunication schemes supported are "tel" (Telephone) and "fax" (Fax)

Telephone example:<telecom use="EC MC" xsi:type="TEL" specializationType="TEL.PHONE" value="tel:+1-780-123-4567"/>

For email addresses: The "URL" property is mandatory and restricted to "mailto".

Email example:<telecom url="mailto" use="WP" xsi:type="TEL" specializationType="TEL.EMAIL"

HL7 V2 Mapping

required NullFlavor = "NI" if no number in source V2 message.

telecom.url.value -> PID.Phone Number - Home.Telephone Number [PID-13.01] (URL property = "tel")

telecom.url.value -> PID.Phone Number - Business.Telephone Number [PID-14.01] (URL property = "tel")

telecom.url.value -> PID.Phone Number - Home.E-mail Address [PID-13.04] (URL property = "mailto")

telecom.url.value -> PID.Phone Number - Home.E-mail Address [PID-14.04] (URL property = "mailto") --

Used, with other patient identity attributes, to confirm patient identity, as well as when addressing the patient. Element is populated because the patient's name is frequently necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry.

(BC PLIS) The lab datatype for patient name supports a Legal name or Pseudonym.

Only one name is permitted.

In BC, Best Practices indicate that the patient name is the Care Card name or a documented name (i.e. supported by identification such as a driver's license)

Allows a patient to be referred to unambiguously. Because this is the principal mechanism for identifying patients to computer systems, the attribute is mandatory. If an identifier is not known, it should be looked up using the 'client registry' capabilities of the EHR application.

Unique identifier assigned to a person by Federal, Provincial and Territorial jurisdiction for the purposes of uniquely identifying the person within the EHR.

The EHR will define which identifier to use within a jurisdiction.

(BC PLIS) cmet requirements: per BC subject identity strategy - for clinical information exchange - in addition to PHN, corroborating demographics (name, DOB and gender) must be supplied on all messages to ensure the correct individual is identified. The purpose of this is not so much about security / privacy as it is about clinical safety: you have to "prove" you have targeted the right person.

The name by which the patient is known to the underlying client registry application

Used to confirm patient identity.

The element is mandatory because the patient's gender is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry and should always be known.
Indicates the gender (sex) of the patient as known by the client registry. Complex genetic genders are handled as observations if they are considered relevant.

This element is 'populated' because the patient's birth date is necessary for positive identification of the patient in the jurisdictional client registry. However, there may be circumstances where the date of birth is not known to the registry.

The specimen material is of primary importance when communicating a lab result.

If not null, then at least one of code (encoded specimen type) or desc (text specimen type) is mandatory.

The specimen code differentiates testing types, methods, and resulting processing of specimen material.

(BC PLIS) PLIS does not support the use of SNOMED CT. Specimen codes are those supplied by the source laboratory. The codesystem OID identifies the code source.

(BC PLIS) Comment: Labs in BC often do not provide this info; in particular if the specimen is already encoded in the LOINC code for the test.
The code of the specimen material collected e.g. skin, blood, etc.

Used when information is not able to be coded or represented using code attributes.

To identify or name the specimen identifier scoping organization.

Identifies the organization or group assigning the associated specimen identifier.

A unique identifier for the organization

(BC PLIS) constraint note does not match old schema definition, in v1.12. What was implemented?

(BC PLIS) the performer is restricted to being an identified organization. It will not be an identified person.

If provided, the performer for the specimen collection will be an organization.

If the collection was performed by a referring organization, this is where it is recorded.
Associates the performer person information with the specimen collection procedure.
(BC PLIS) Conformance level increased, was: Required.
For communicating the associated specimen collection procedure information.
(BC PLIS) points to specimen collection information; in particular the collection time, which must be supplied if known.
Associates the specimen (role) with the collection procedure (information).
The specimen role represents the information regarding a material collected from a patient to serve as a specimen for testing.
(BC PLIS) constrained classcode to "SPEC"
A unique specimen identifier is necessary for specimen tracking and management.
(BC PLIS) Laboratory LIS assigned specimen identifier.

A unique identifier for the specimen. Frequently the accession number which often uniquely identifies the specimen is used as the unique specimen identifier in communications. However, accessioning may group multiple specimens (identified) under one accession number. Therefore, it is recommended that this be truly the specimen identifier and not the accession number.

For a referral, this attribute should be Required so it is reflected back in the result. If Lab A has collected and or done something to the specimen, then the identifier would be sent.
(BC PLIS) PLIS missing mandatory fixed value in some query response messages. Issue #SP185.
(BC PLIS) Note fixed value.
The specimen is a product of a specimen collection procedure. This productOf participation associates an identified specimen with the documentation of that specimen's collection process.
For certain laboratory tests, the specimen collection procedure information is relevant in determining the result value.
This is the procedure act which describes the process/procedure used to collect the associated specimen.

The text attribute documents any additional information regarding this specimen collection procedure event that is not able to be communicated using the other attribution of this act e.g. for granularity of coding reasons.

(BC PLIS) Additional text information related to the specimen collection procedure (e.g. comments).

HL7 V2 Mapping

Note: the model component Material.desc is used to qualify the specimen - site / source.

Used to describe any additional information regarding the specimen collection procedure or the collected material, e.g. left ear; where "ear" is atomically represented by the Natural entity code but the "left" is not able, at this time, to also be communicated within the Natural entity. This attribute is not used for notes or comments regarding the specimen collection process. Notes and annotations are documented using the Annotation CMET.
(BC PLIS) changed conformance level, was: Required.

(BC PLIS) Conformance issue. Query response message uses wrong markup for point in time value. This is a markup error and a datatype error. Issue #SP170.

(BC PLIS) PLIS use of datatype ts.fulldatetime is non-conformant because it pads out time component if time is not specified by source Lab. (PLIS should be using ts.fulldatewithtime.) Issue #SP385.
The specimen collection date/time is relevant to the testing and resulting outcome of that specimen for some laboratory tests.

(BC PLIS) Specimen Collection Date and Time

For drop-off specimens, the collection time is sometimes not know. Labs will often default the time to midnight or noon to get around timestamp requirements within the LIS.

(BC PLIS) Use Null Flavor "NI" No information if not known.

BC PLIS) markup for Intervals and Single Values

To ensure the models are reusable, some attributes are set to support an interval of values. This also

provides support for a single value.

For any attribute set to IVL<some data type>, use xsi:type in the message instance set to the single data type.

For example, if an attribute is set to IVL<TS.FULLDATETIME> in the message model definition, then in the message instance a single value (only) can be populated as follows:

<effectiveTime xsi:type="TS" specializationType="TS.FULLDATETIME" value="200508021730-0800"/>

The date/time the specimen was collected. This can be a date/time interval (start - stop).

The time may not always be known, but a date should always be entered.
(BC PLIS) is this attribute supported by PLIS? issue #SP400.
Method of specimen collection used primarily for Surgical Pathology.

To capture, communicate collector's notes.

The state or status of this transportation process step.

If the performer is not specified in the message, the performer is the author from the ControlActEvent.

HL7 v2 MAPPING:

The author will be the same as the performer for the associated event.

The inherited default is necessary because an author is not specified in a HL7 v2 [NTE] segment.

For BC lab messages, the author will always be the performing organization. There is no business rule identified to specify the person.

The performing lab may have been defaulted to the sending facility (depending on the implementation); this does not affect the assignment of the author.

Example: if the note is associated with a result event, then the performer of the result event will be the author of the associated annotation.

Example: if the note is associated with a collection event, then the performer of the collection event will be the author of the associated annotation

(BC PLIS) Constraint: For datatypes used to communicate a testing outcome, either the value or the originalText must be provided and not null.

HL7 V2 MAPPING

Implementation / mapping consideration:

If the lab designates a null result but associates a note record, the note record is, effectively, the result value. The handling of heavy text results by using null result values with extended text reported in NTE records may be a mechanism used by individual LISs. Example: an interpretation text.

If the laboratory cannot report a result and so reports a null result with a message stating that the result cannot be given, the result value may be appropriately reported as a null value (e.g. not given).

This is an issue that needs to be identified during implementation.

It may, in some circumstances, be considered an "acceptable level of non-conformance".

The datatype ANY.x1 allows many lines of text to permit heavy text to be reported.

If units of measure are provided, then the value will be mapped using the PQ datatype.

If the value is text and units of measure are provided, then the value will be a null flavor, the units property will be used and the lab text will be in the originalText property.

For example, a result of None Seen with units of "mmol/L":

<value xsi:type="PQ" specializationType="PQ.LAB" nullFlavor="OTH" unit="mmol/L"><originalText>None Seen</originalText></value>
The result value.

If there is no flag, then a flag should not be displayed.

If a flag is "N" (normal), then the result is normal. This flag value must not be used for any alert functionality related to abnormal or critical results.

(BC PLIS)

RESULT MESSAGE:

There is no mechanism for the source LIS's to provide the report status in an HL7 v2 message. Thus, the value of the statusCode from the LIS will typically be NI (no information).

There may be LISs that can supply a report status. This is not typical and will be addressed when such LIS's are brought on board.

When a report status is not available from a source LIS, the PLIS application will derive the statusCode value from the current message and any previous messages with the same ObservationReport.id as follows:

- active: at least one component result has a status that is less than 'completed'.

- completed: all component result statuses are 'completed'.

QUERY RESPONSE:

In response to a query the PLIS application will supply the (derived) ObservationReport.statusCode.

The status or state of the report. The statusCode is not as fine-grained as lab reporting statuses such as preliminary. A "preliminary" result is a result whose statusCode=active and ProcessStep (procedure event) valued "preliminary".

(BC PLIS) QUERY RESPONSE (Patient-Centric)

PLIS Query responses are always for a single, identified patient, as specified in the ControlActEvent recordtarget. The patient demographics in ControlActEvent.recordTarget.patient1.* should reflect the patient identification specified in the Query Request.

However, patient demographics may change over time (e.g. patient identifier, spelling of name, alternate identifiers, identifying characteristics). The patient demographics included here, observationReport.recordTarget.* are as of the time of the lab result report.

(BC PLIS). Process status is summarized from child observations as follows:

If all Observations have the same process status (Preliminary, Final or Corrected), then that is what appears here.

If a mix of Final + Preliminary, then the process status is Preliminary.

If a mix of Final + Corrected, then Corrected

If a mix of Preliminary + Corrected, then Corrected.

If a mix of Preliminary + Final + Corrected, then Corrected.

(BC PLIS) markup for Intervals and Single Values

To ensure the models are reusable, some attributes are set to support an interval of values. This also

provides support for a single value.

For any attribute set to IVL<some data type>, use xsi:type in the message instance set to the single data type.

For example, if an attribute is set to IVL<TS.FULLDATETIME> in the message model definition, then in the message instance a single value (only) can be populated as follows:

<effectiveTime xsi:type="TS" specializationType="TS.FULLDATETIME" value="200508021730-0800"/>

(BC PLIS) SNOMED CT code for the micro-organism.

The SNOMED CT code will be stored in the PLIS Domain repository.

The SNOMED CT code is conveyed using the CV datatype.

The display name in the CV datatype is the reportable display name.

If the lab does not supply the SNOMED CT code, the value is UNK (unknown). The value UNK is not a reportable result.

If the value is UNK, then the [desc] attribute is used instead of the code and none of the information in the code is reportable.

(BC PLIS) The identification of the micro-organism in a text format.

If the SNOMED CT code has been supplied, then any text in the [desc] attribute will be reported in addition to the display name supplied with the SNOMED CT code.

If the SNOMED CT code has not be supplied or the .code value is a flavour of null (e.g. UNK), then this text field identifies the organism and is reportable as the micro-organism identification.
Text name or description of the Microorganism. Only to be used if SNOMED is not supported.

The statusCode represents the "state" of the act e.g. active=in progress or not yet started, complete=final.

(BC PLIS) There is no mechanism for the LIS to provide the report status in the HL7 v2 source message to PLIS.

When a report status is not available from a source LIS, the PLIS application will derive the statusCode value from the current message and any previous messages with the same ObservationReport.id as follows:

- active: at least one component result has a status that is less than 'completed'.

- completed: all component result statuses are 'completed'.

HL7 V2 MAPPING

there is no generic mapping from the HL7 V2 message to the report status. However, a specific lab implementation may supply the report status.

The status or state of the report. The statusCode is not as fine-grained as lab reporting statuses such as preliminary. A "preliminary" result is a result whose statusCode=active and ProcessStep (procedure event) valued "preliminary".

(BC PLIS) QUERY RESPONSE (Patient-Centric)

PLIS Query responses are always for a single, identified patient, as specified in the ControlActEvent recordtarget. The patient demographics specified in [ ControlActEvent.recordTarget.patient1.*] should reflect the patient identification specified in the Query Request.

However, patient demographics may change over time (e.g. patient identifier, spelling of name, alternate identifiers, identifying characteristics). The patient demographics included here, [observationReport.recordTarget.*] are as of the time of the lab result report.

This identifies the patient associated with the query response record. This participation is used only for multi-patient query response messages (for single patient messages, the record target patient is identified in the control act). For lab, this participation and associated CMET are populated in the Result Query Response Provider or Location Message (only).

(BC PLIS) The sensitivityBattery is a battery code that groups the sensitivities within the cluster.
This act "groups" all the sensitivity tests performed on a particular isolate. The battery may be made up of individual sensitivity tests using all the same testing method or using differing methods.

(BC PLIS) pCLOCD code that identifies the sensitivity battery.

This is usually used as a grouping mechanism for sensitivity observation events. A code is not generally available, in which case a nullflavor of NI will be supplied as the code. A nullflavor is not reportable.

HL7 V2 MAPPING ISSUE:

Some LISs may not identify the Sensitivity Battery. The battery is considered to have "started" when the first sensitivity is found. The sensitivity battery is "ended" when either a result that is not a sensitivity or a new battery is identified.

In this case, the Sensitivity Battery does not require a code. It is an implementation decision whether to assign a generic sensitivity battery code in this case.
Generally describes the sensitivity battery being performed, e.g. viral, microbial, etc.

(BC PLIS). Process status is summarized from child observations as follows:

If all Observations have the same process status (Preliminary, Final or Corrected), then that is what appears here.

If a mix of Final + Preliminary, then the process status is Preliminary.

If a mix of Final + Corrected, then Corrected

If a mix of Preliminary + Corrected, then Corrected.

If a mix of Preliminary + Final + Corrected, then Corrected.

The statusCode represents the "state" of the act e.g. active=in progress or not yet started, complete=final.

(BC PLIS)

RESULT MESSAGE:

There is no mechanism for the source LIS's to provide the report status in an HL7 v2 message.

The value of the statusCode from the LIS will typically be "NI" (no information).

There may be LISs that can supply a report status. This is not typical and will be addressed when such LIS's are brought on board.

When a report status is not available from a source LIS, the PLIS application will derive the statusCode value from the current message and any previous messages with the same ObservationReport.id as follows:

- active - at least one component result has a status that is less than 'completed'.

- completed - all component result statuses are 'completed'.

QUERY RESPONSE: In response to a query the PLIS application will supply the (derived) ObservationReport.statusCode.

The status or state of the report. The statusCode is not as fine-grained as lab reporting statuses such as preliminary. A "preliminary" result is a result whose statusCode=active and ProcessStep (procedure event) valued "preliminary".

This may be satisfied through inheritance, as follows:

> Performers designated for the ObservationReport will be considered to be the performer for each component Battery Event.

> Performers designated for a BatteryEvent will be considered to be the performer for each component Observation event.

In other words, in one message, one performer designated for the ObservationReport satisfies the data requirements for all components of the report.

(BC PLIS) QUERY RESPONSE (Patient-Centric)

PLIS Query responses are always for a single, identified patient, as specified in the ControlActEvent recordtarget. The patient demographics specified IN ControlActEvent.recordTarget.patient1.* should reflect the patient identification specified in the Query Request.

However, patient demographics may change over time (e.g. patient identifier, spelling of name, alternate identifiers, identifying characteristics). The patient demographics included here, observationReport.recordTarget.* are as of the time of the lab result report.

This identifies the patient associated with the query response record. This participation is used only for multi-patient query response messages (for single patient messages, the record target patient is identified in the control act). For lab, this participation and associated CMET are populated in the Result Query Response Provider or Location Message (only).

(BC PLIS) The battery status must be supplied by the LIS.

(BC PLIS) markup for Intervals and Single Values

To ensure the models are reusable, some attributes are set to support an interval of values. This also

provides support for a single value.

For any attribute set to IVL<some data type>, use xsi:type in the message instance set to the single data type.

For example, if an attribute is set to IVL<TS.FULLDATETIME> in the message model definition, then in the

message instance a single value (only) can be populated as follows:

<effectiveTime xsi:type="TS" specializationType="TS.FULLDATETIME" value="200508021730-0800"/>

documentation.businessName: Specimen Collected Date Time Range Parameter

annotation.text: Allows constraining the retrieved records to those applicable at a particular time.

(BC PLIS) Based on the specimen collection date in the result messages.

(BC PLIS) The tests on one report may be performed on specimens collected at different times. Therefore, a report that is returned may contain tests for specimens collected outside the time range specified.

(BC PLIS) Where a PoS allows the entry of a date with no time and the parameter requires both a time and a date, the PoS will default the time portion. In a date range, the lower bound of the range would default to the earliest possible time on that date (i.e. 0000) and the upper bound of the range would default to the latest possible time on that date (i.e. 23:59). For example, if a user specifies March 10, 2010 to March 12, 2010, then the range will effectively be 00:00 March 10, 2010 through midnight March 12, 2010 (all records collected on the date).

Where a record in the repository is stored with a date but not time, the record will be included in the response if the date-only portion matches or falls within the date range regardless of whether the parameter includes a time.

Within the repository, dates may be stored as intervals with a start and end time or as a point in time.

Only one date range per parameter is permitted.

Both the start date and the end date for the parameter must be provided. The start date must precede the end date. If the start and end date are equal, then the search is, effectively, for a specific date.

The query response will include all records with a date that is within the date range (inclusive) and that match the other query parameters specified.

When the repository date is an interval, the interval end date must be within the target range to be considered a match and returned in the Query Response.

The start date of the interval does not have to be within the target date range but the end date must be.

Filters the set of records to be retrieved to those which the specimen collection date/time for the patient within the time boundaries specified. Either the lower bound or upper bound or both would be specified. If no value is specified, no filter will be applied. If there is any overlap between the specified time-range and the specimen collection date/time, the record will be returned.
(BC PLIS) 8-may-2012. confirm revised implementation notes. Issue #202, #204
Allows constraining the retrieved records to those applicable at a particular time.

(BC PLIS) Lab message payload times are stored with a GMT offset based on the local time of the reporting LIS.

The Clinical times in the HL7 V3 response message will match exactly the time reported by the LIS in the original HL7 V3 PUT message. This includes the Date, Time and Timezone offset components of the time values.

The requesting PoS for query messages will send the parameter time values in its local time and specify the timezone offset as per HL7 datatype specifications. PLIS will calculate the difference, if any.

(BC PLIS) When this Query parameter is used, the start and end date must be provided. No other time properties are permitted.

(BC PLIS) A PoS may provide user functionality that allows a date to be specified with no time. When this occurs and where the parameter datatype requires both a time and a date, the PoS should extend the date so that the time is defaulted

(BC PLIS) If a query request contains a partial date/time the BC PLIS treats it as follows: "When searching in the PLIS the following assumption will be made: when only partial date/times are provided to complete the date/time value. E.g. 2009 will be interpreted as 2009-01-01 00:00:00 for "low" values and 2009-12-31 23:59:59 for "high" values.

Filters the set of records to be retrieved to those for which the specimen collection date/time falls within a particular time period. The time period can have an upper and lower bound, or be open at either end of the range. If no value is specified, no filter will be applied. If there is any overlap between the specified time-range and the actual specimen collection date/time, the record will be returned; in other words an exact match is not required. This maps to SpecimenCollectionProcedureEvent.effectiveTime in the response model.

(BC PLIS) BC model extension, cloned from RIM QueryContinuation class. Class and attributes are defined in a separate namespace, per HL7 model extension protocols.
(BC PLIS) Non-standard use of RIM model (but enabled as a local extension).
(BC PLIS) Page control makes it possible to execute a series of queries that cover the full range of a very large number of result records too many to return in a single response.

(BC PLIS). pagination control class. BC adaption of HL7 query protocol, that looks like query continuation, but in fact triggers execution of a new query with no relation to any previous query. The 'illusion' of query continuation is given by the Start Result NumberNumber that identifies the first battery that the set should start with.
(BC PLIS) See class annotations.
(BC PLIS) identifies query result records that are to be eliminated from the final query response payload

(BC PLIS): 'record' for the purposes of this lab result query is equivalent to 'Battery'.

(BC PLIS) The startResultNumber for an initial request should be '1'.
BC PLIS. The first record that the result set should start with (e.g. start with the 201st battery in the set)
Used to filter the information returned by the query. All queries must have parameters, therefore this element is mandatory.
References the parameter names and the values used by the query.

(BC PLIS) conformance error. mandatory element not supported. Issue #SP215
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.

Unique number for this particular query.

(BC PLIS) maps to business data element, Query Page Size: The number of batteries that should be returned per page.

(BC PLIS) changed max length from 3.
(BC PLIS) BC datatype change is not conformant to Cdn specification.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.

HL7: If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.

(BC PLIS). There is a default maximum record limit for PLIS that will not be exceeded, regardless of the setting of this parameter. PLIS will return a warning if the limit rule has been applied.

(BC PLIS) The [initialQuantity] can be set to 0 (zero), in which case only record counts will be returned, in POLB_IN384000CAqueryAck.resultTotalQuantity. There will be no clinical payload.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.
(BC PLIS) set fixed value
(BC PLIS) In the PLIS detail query this attribute has simple CV datatype. Need to confirm that these are compatible.
Needed to quantify the types of records requested to be returned in the query.

(BC PLIS) The RIM vocabulary for QueryRequestLimit has only one value, RD (=record). This will be interpreted as = 'Battery' for PLIS purposes. Thus the initial page size limit (HL7: InitialQuantity) is interpreted as "number of batteries" to be returned.
Defines the units associated with the magnitude of the maximum size limit of a query response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
(BC PLIS) changed target cmet model for BC PLIS version. Was COCT_MT050202CA.

Inferring patient identity opens up the potential for privacy breach through the mis-keying of identifiers. Also, inclusion of patient identity simplifies logging, processing and application of data access constraints such as masking and consent. Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).

Patient identity is key to successful operation of the EHR.

A bare identifier exposes the patient to potential privacy violation.
BC PLIS: target constrained to a single cmet that contains an id plus identifying patient demographics (as required by BC EMPI). These are the same parameters used for HIAL validation.

Associated patient record for which this message applies. Record target can be one of either identified patient (id, name, gender, date of birth), indeterminate patient (name, gender, date of birth) or a patient token (suggesting client identity).
(BC PLIS) BC model adaptation of the HL7 UV spec. Sort controls are not present in the standard pan-Canadian query wrappers.
required in order to complete the query sort instructions.
specifies the (ordinal) order in which the elements are sorted.

(BC PLIS) created new concpet domain LabSummaryElementName to distiguish lab sort parameters from those used in other queries. This is a BC work-around for the HL7 domain ElementName, which is not specific enough.
(BC PLIS) this element uses the HL7 'SC' datatype. There isn't a defined Cdn flavor, nor is this datatype currently used by PLIS. (BC PLIS) domain LabSummaryElementName is not defined in the RIM.
identifies the data on which to base the sort. Required in order to complete the query sort instructions.

BC-PLIS: the "ElementName" valueset lists all of the sort parameters that are supported by the PLIS application. See the Terminology worksheet.

BC-PLIS: A sort element name must match to a query parameter in the query request payload.

HL7: identifies a RIM element in a query response.

BC-PLIS: identifies a query parameter element on which the response data is to sorted. That parameter maps to a RIM element in the response message.
required in order to construct the query sort request
(BC PLIS) Coding is limited to A(scending) or D(escending), one of which must be supplied.
RIM: specifies sequence of sort order (values are ascending, descending, or none)
